content.description: Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) is characterized by a pervasive pattern of disregard for, and violation of, the rights of others. It involves deceit, impulsivity, irritability/aggressiveness, irresponsibility, and lack of remorse, beginning in childhood or early adolescence and continuing into adulthood.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. A pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others occurring since age 15 years, as indicated by ≥3 of: (1) Failure to conform to social norms/laws, (2) Deceitfulness, (3) Impulsivity/failure to plan, (4) Irritability/aggressiveness, (5) Reckless disregard for safety of self/others, (6) Consistent irresponsibility, (7) Lack of remorse. B. At least age 18. C. Evidence of Conduct Disorder before age 15. D. Occurrence not exclusively during schizophrenia or bipolar disorder.
content.prevalence: Approximately 0.2–3.3% in the general population; higher in forensic and substance-using populations.
content.age_of_onset: Behavioral symptoms begin in childhood with Conduct Disorder; full diagnosis not made until age 18.
content.prognosis: Tends to be chronic; symptoms may remit with age, especially after the 40s, but core traits often persist. Associated with increased morbidity, mortality, and legal problems.

circuitry: Abnormalities in prefrontal cortex and amygdala linked to impaired impulse control, empathy, and fear conditioning.
neurochemistry: Dysregulation of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: High heritability; childhood abuse, neglect, unstable family environment, and exposure to violence increase risk.

history_psychosocial: Criminal/legal history, relationship patterns, occupational stability.
medical_assessment: Screen for traumatic brain injury, substance effects, and co-occurring psychiatric disorders.
risk_stratification: High risk for violence, criminal behavior, substance abuse.
evaluation.team_and_process: Multidisciplinary management including psychiatry, psychology, social services, and forensic specialists when indicated.

severity_levels.mild: Few antisocial behaviors, occasional legal issues, partial functioning.
severity_levels.moderate: Multiple antisocial behaviors, recurrent legal issues, impaired relationships and work functioning.
severity_levels.severe: Persistent and pervasive antisocial behaviors, repeated criminal acts, high danger to others.

biological: Family history of ASPD or conduct disorder
Genetic predisposition to impulsivity and aggression

impact_on_life.school_work: Frequent job loss, poor performance, conflicts with authority.
impact_on_life.medical: Increased risk of injury, substance-related illnesses.
impact_on_life.emotional: Chronic anger, lack of emotional depth.

psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) targeting problem-solving and impulse control.
Schema-focused therapy for entrenched maladaptive patterns.
medications: No FDA-approved medications; consider SSRIs for aggression/impulsivity, mood stabilizers for affective lability, and antipsychotics for severe aggression.
lifestyle_interventions: Structured routines, avoidance of high-risk environments.
care_coordination: Social services for housing, employment, substance treatment.

treatment_goals: Reduce antisocial behaviors and legal involvement.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Failure to document conduct disorder before age 15.
Misattributing antisocial behaviors solely to substance use.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling individuals with criminal history without full criteria.
Misdiagnosing in the context of situational antisocial acts.
warning_signs: Loss of housing or employment due to behavior

childhood: Conduct disorder symptoms such as truancy, aggression, property destruction.
adolescence: Escalation of conduct issues, legal troubles.
adulthood: Persistence of antisocial behaviors; some decline with age.

real_life_examples: A 28-year-old repeatedly engages in fraud, changes residences to avoid rent, and shows no remorse despite multiple convictions.
A 40-year-old with a history of assaults and theft begins CBT in a mandated court program and reduces reoffending over 2 years.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek help if repeated unlawful behavior, aggression, or inability to maintain employment/relationships causes significant life disruption.
